Module 8, Section 5: Knowledge Check

Intermediate Section 5 of 7

üéØ Overview üìö Concepts üö∂ Walkthrough üíª Labs ‚úÖ Quiz üìñ Resources üíº Scenarios

Questions

Question 1: What‚Äôs the difference between workflow_run and needs for workflow/job dependencies?

View Answer

needs - Job dependency within a workflow:

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps: [...]
    
  deploy:
    needs: build  # Runs after build job completes
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps: [...]
  • Same workflow file
  • Shares workflow context (secrets, variables)
  • Can access outputs from needed jobs workflow_run - Workflow dependency across workflows:
on:
  workflow_run:
    workflows: ["CI"]
    branches: [main]
    types: [completed]
  • Different workflow files
  • Separate workflow runs
  • Need to explicitly download artifacts
  • Can filter by branch and completion status Use cases:
  • needs: Sequential jobs in same pipeline (build ‚Üí test ‚Üí deploy)
  • workflow_run: Triggered pipelines (CI completes ‚Üí trigger CD)

Question 2: A production deployment failed and you need to rollback immediately. What are your options?

View Answer

Option 1: Kubernetes native rollback

kubectl rollout undo deployment/my-app
kubectl rollout status deployment/my-app

Option 2: GitHub Actions rollback workflow

workflow_dispatch:
  inputs:
    version:
      required: true

Redeploy a previous known-good version. Option 3: Blue-Green swap

# If using Azure App Service slots
az webapp deployment slot swap --slot staging --target-slot production
# If using AWS/load balancer
# Switch target group to previous environment

Option 4: GitOps rollback

# If using GitOps (Flux, ArgoCD)
git revert <bad-commit>
git push
# GitOps controller auto-deploys previous state

Best practice: - Have rollback procedures documented - Test rollback regularly - Keep previous 3-5 versions available - Monitor after rollback to confirm resolution

Question 3: How do you prevent deployments to production on Fridays?

View Answer

Option 1: Workflow condition

deploy-production:
  if: github.event.schedule != 'friday' && 
      (steps.date.outputs.day != 'Friday')
  
  steps:
    - name: Check day
      id: date
      run: echo "day=$(date +%A)" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
      
    - name: Block Friday deploys
      if: steps.date.outputs.day == 'Friday'
      run: |
        echo "No production deploys on Fridays!"
        exit 1

Option 2: Custom deployment protection rule - Create an external service that returns deploy status - Configure as custom deployment protection - Service checks day/time and returns proceed/reject Option 3: Branch protection with scheduled windows - Require PR approval - Only approve production PRs Mon-Thu - Document policy in CODEOWNERS Option 4: Environment wait timer - Set 72-hour wait timer on Friday evenings - Effectively blocks until Monday Best approach: Combine technical controls with policy. Document ‚Äúno Friday deploys‚Äù and enforce with workflow checks.

Question 4: How do you share secrets between environments without duplicating them?

View Answer

Option 1: Repository secrets (shared)

# Repository secret available to all environments
env:
  COMMON_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.SHARED_API_KEY }}

Option 2: Organization secrets (shared across repos) - Organization Settings ‚Üí Secrets - Choose repository access policy - Available in all selected repos/environments Option 3: Azure Key Vault / AWS Secrets Manager

- name: Get secrets from Key Vault
  uses: azure/get-keyvault-secrets@v1
  with:
    keyvault: "my-key-vault"
    secrets: 'API-KEY,DB-PASSWORD'
  id: secrets

Option 4: Environment inheritance (not native)

# Custom solution: fetch from common environment
- name: Get shared secrets
  run: |
    # API call to get shared secrets
    # Or use organization variables

Best practice: - Use repository secrets for truly shared values - Use environment secrets for environment-specific - Use external secret managers for rotation/audit

Question 5: Explain how to implement a deployment approval workflow that requires sign-off from both QA and Security teams.

View Answer

Configuration: 1. Create teams: - @org/qa-team - @org/security-team 2. Configure environment protection:

Environment: production
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Required reviewers:
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ @org/qa-team (any 1)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ @org/security-team (any 1)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Deployment branches: main
  1. Workflow configuration:
jobs:
  qa-validation:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment: qa-gate  # QA approves here
    steps:
      - run: echo "QA approved"
      
  security-validation:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    environment: security-gate  # Security approves here
    steps:
      - run: echo "Security approved"
      
  deploy:
    needs: [qa-validation, security-validation]
    environment: production
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - run: echo "Deploying..."
  1. Alternative: Single environment with multiple reviewers
Environment: production
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Required reviewers:
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ @org/qa-team (any 1)
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ @org/security-team (any 1)
‚îÇ   Require both teams: Yes

Note: GitHub natively supports requiring approval from multiple teams when they‚Äôre all listed as required reviewers.
